PREFACE
The following oral history testimony is the result of a videotaped interview with Julian
Bussgang, conducted on December 17, 2002 on behalf of the United States Holocaust Memorial
Museum. The interview is part of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's collection of
oral testimonies. Rights to the interview are held by the United States Holocaust Memorial
Museum.

JULIAN BUSSGANG
December 17, 2002
Beginning Tape One

segments.question: Good morning, Julian.
segments.answer: Good morning.

segments.question: Nice to have you in Washington.
segments.answer: Nice to be here.

segments.question: Tell me when you were born.
segments.answer: I was born on March 26, 1925.

segments.question: And where were you born?
segments.answer: I was born in Lwow, Poland, now it’s called Lviv, U-Ukraine.

segments.question: And what was your name at birth?
segments.answer: My name at birth was Julian and actually my middle name Jacob, and my father and mother decided to call me Julian because they wanted an international name and they thought Julian, if I ever went -- were to travel, would work well.

segments.question: And your last name was Bussgang?
segments.answer: Exactly.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: And the same spelling. It’s really important to get a sense of what your family was like, so let’s talk about your mother and father and sister, and your memories of that early time in Lwow.
segments.answer: My father was a very serious man. He was born in Rohatyn, which is town south of Lwow, and he started his schooling in [indecipherable] but decided to leave it and went to regular public This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  2 school. And then he went to an educational seminary to become a teacher and then he became inspector of schools, and then he went into business and moved to Lwow. And my mother’s - her maiden name w-was Philip, and she was from Lwow, and her mother was from Krakow. And my parents married, my father was already a little older, I think, and he was like nine years older than my mother, and -- and they had two children, my sister Janina, or Janine as you would say in English, and myself. My sister was born in 1923, I was born in 1925. There was only like a year and a half difference between us, so we were very close. And we were a very close family. My father worked in an office downstairs in the same house where we lived, and actually my mother worked with him, and we had help, domestic help in the apartment. And we were a close family mostly, with my mother’s sisters, my aunts and uncles. And I had a very warm and nice childhood. I grew up very secure.

segments.question: Tell me what did your father do? What sort of business was it?
segments.answer: He was representing a number of large companies in the region like Lever Brothers and some companies from Holland. And it was mostly products that didn’t require refrigeration, was like starch and -- and soap powders, things like this. And so a -- and he was in business of selling to retailers, so that actually he was quite -- we weren’t overly rich, but we were very well-to-so.

segments.question: So when -- when you were born, he was already fairly successful?
segments.answer: He was fairly successful, yes.

segments.question: Right. So you -- you grew up in a fairly privileged environment, I guess.
segments.answer: Right, right, and my mother’s family, one of my uncles was a very prominent physician and another uncle was a banker and -

segments.question: Uh-huh. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  3
segments.answer: -- and had his own bank. And he was the one who arranged the marriage betwe -- my father had been his client -- between my mother my father.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: He got them acquainted.

segments.question: Tell me about the per -- your relationship to your father and your relationship to your mother. Were you closer to one than to the other?
segments.answer: I may have been a little bit closer to my mother, and my father may have been a little closer to my sister.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: But actually we were all pretty close because we were all in the same house.

segments.question: House, right.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Did you ever work with your father? Did you ever -
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: -- go into the [indecipherable]? No, you didn’t.
segments.answer: Never. I was a very good student as a child, and -- and because my sister was a year and a half older than myself, I f-followed her very closely and I went to school early, because once she went to school, I wanted to go to school.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So I was always the youngest in my class.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And I also had private tutoring in German and private tutoring in mathematics because I was particularly interested in mathematics. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  4

segments.question: Mathematics.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Were you also close with your sister?
segments.answer: I was very close with my sister. We actually shared a room for a long time.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: And was she good to you as an older sister?
segments.answer: Ah, sh -- well, we were a little jealous of each other sometimes, but she was good to me, yes.

segments.question: And what were you jealous about?
segments.answer: Because she was a year older, so she was doing things a little bit ahead of me, but -- but we became even closer when we became refugees.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Because then the family got really close.

segments.question: Did you ever do things alone with your father or alone with your mother, going for walks, or going to -- I don’t know if there were cultural things in the city, or to a museum?
segments.answer: Mostly I was doing things with my sister with the people who were taking care of us. But we s -- seldom -- my father was very serious, he was seldom playful with us.

segments.question: He was seldom playful?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Uh-huh. And your mother was more so?
segments.answer: My mother a little more so, but she also was very busy working and looking after things in the house, yeah.

segments.question: Uh-huh. So did you -- did you have a lot of help in the house? Did you ha - This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  5
segments.answer: We had somebody who cooked, and somebody who cleaned.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And then as babies we had -- once we had a fraulein, a German lady, and once we had a mademoiselle, a French mademoiselle, so -- who took us for walks, yeah.

segments.question: So did you learn both languages? How many languages?
segments.answer: I -- I learned Fr-French and German. Of course, we spoke Polish at home, and -- and then during the war I learned a little Hebrew and Italian because I was in Italy.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: So when I met my wife I told her I knew five languages, and she was impressed.

segments.question: And did she test you on that? No.
segments.answer: Tested my French and she’s pretty good at French herself.

segments.question: Were you in an environment where Polish Jews and Polish Christians were mixing, that you yourself were within a very integrated kind of setting, or not?
segments.answer: Yes. Socially, a-and family-wise, the family was Jewish and most of our close friends were Jewish, but -- but we were an assimilated family and we were in quite an integrated environment and I went to a school where majority of the kids were not Jewish and -- both in the elementary school and in the high school. I went to public high school.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I went to a private elementary school because I was too young to go to the public high school, and the private school took me in.

segments.question: And was this a comfortable environment? When you say that you were assimilated as Jews, did this also mean that you celebrated Jewish holidays and went to the synagogue, or you didn’t?
segments.answer: Oh yes. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  6

segments.question: You did?
segments.answer: We definitely -- my parents belonged to what was called the temple, which is the -- was the largest synagogue in the city, and it was called Progressive Judaism, which 1s similar to American Conservative Judaism. And -- and my father had a seat, you had to buy seats and my father had a seat downstairs and my mother had a seat on the balcony, in the -

segments.question: Where the women sat.
segments.answer: Yeah. And I sat with my dad, yeah.

segments.question: And your sister sat upstairs, or with you?
segments.answer: Yes, upstairs, yes, yes.

segments.question: Upstairs. So did you go during the holidays, or did you go every Shabbat, or -
segments.answer: No, no, we went just during holidays.

segments.question: Holidays.
segments.answer: Yeah, right. My parents were not very religious.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But they definitely were Jewish, but not extremely religious.

segments.question: Not -- right. So I could -- should I assume that you were not kosher in the house?
segments.answer: We were not kosher.

segments.question: Yes. Or anywhere, actually.
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: And how was it for you to be in a -
segments.answer: We ate matzoh on Passover - This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  7

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: -- but sometimes I had ham on the matzoh.

segments.question: On the -- [laughs]. Did you experience anti-Semitism as you were growing up?
segments.answer: As I was growing up there was anti-Semitism growing in Poland, beginning around 1934, and it was particularly evident at universities, and -- because Jewish students were not -- were told to sit in back benches and were not allowed sometimes to -- to even attempt classes [indecipherable]. And -- and some of the -- interestingly enough, the university students were what was called open index. N -- N.D. stands for National Democracy which is -- was the sort of right wing party, which was very anti-Semitic, and they sometimes would make -- not pogroms in the sense that somebody was completely bludgeoned to death, but they would beat up J-Jews in the street occasionally. And I learned to avoid big gangs of students, and -- and sometimes there were just stupid people who were anti-Semitic, but most of the people in the city were very well integrated because the -- the city itself had been under Austrian occupation and had a lot of Jew -- 30 percent of the residents were Jews, and -- and in addition Polish Catholics, there were Greek Orthodox, and there were Ukrainians and there were Armenians, so it was kind of cosmopolitan [indecipherable]

segments.question: Right. And your close friends? You had Jewish friends, and Polish friends?
segments.answer: I had Jewish friends and Polish friends, but in terms of going to homes of kids, I was closest to the Jewish boys.

segments.question: And did you notice that that was because there was a kind of division, or you think it was just happenstance?
segments.answer: Mostly because sometimes -- it was partly because there was a little division, yeah. But I was very friendly with many of non-Jewish - This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  8

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- people.

segments.question: Let -- let me go back a little bit. Were you interested in mathematics as a very tiny kid? And
segments.answer: I was very interested in mathematics, yes.

segments.question: Wa -- were -- was this coming from your parents, I mean is there some way to trace it, or it just -- do you know?
segments.answer: No, it’s just a natural interest. Some kids are interested in music.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: I was never very musical.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: I liked just playing chess and doing mathematics.

segments.question: I see. Were there any other subject matters that were of interest to you, or was this your real passion [indecipherable |
segments.answer: This -

segments.question: Mm’?
segments.answer: -- this was the real passion. I was somewhat interested 1n history.

segments.question: Did you go to the movies as a kid? This is before the war, I mean [indecipherable]
segments.answer: Yes. I went to movies, and I also went to -- we had in Lwow an opera house, and occasionally I went to performances, both opera and theater.

segments.question: Did you like that?
segments.answer: I liked it, yes.

segments.question: Yes. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  9
segments.answer: The opera house in Lwow is beautiful.

segments.question: And do you [indecipherable]
segments.answer: It has survived, and 1s -

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: -- and it’s been re-remodeled and is just like it used to be.

segments.question: A-And do you remember any particular opera?
segments.answer: Not really.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: Got more interested in opera in that way then.

segments.question: Uh-huh. And theater? Do you remember any theater that you went to?
segments.answer: I remember going to theater, but -- but I don’t remember -

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- s-specific performances.

segments.question: And when you went to the movies, did you go with your sister, or you went with a bunch of kids? Do you have any recollection, or you don’t -
segments.answer: I don’t recollect.

segments.question: Did you have a favorite food when you were a kid?
segments.answer: Not really. I -- I never paid much attention to food.

segments.question: And when you ate dinner at the house, or ate -
segments.answer: I -- I liked -- my mother made carp Jewish style, sometimes.

segments.question: Yeah?
segments.answer: In jelly, I liked that.

segments.question: Gefilte fish? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  10
segments.answer: Gefilte fish, yes.

segments.question: Uh-huh. And she cooked that?
segments.answer: She cooked that, yes.

segments.question: Huh. And when -- when you all were home and eating lunch and dinner, did you all eat together? Your father came in, and you ate together?
segments.answer: Yes. We ate together in the dining room -

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- and we were served.

segments.question: You were served dinner, uh-huh.
segments.answer: Yes. [indecipherable]

segments.question: Now, was this a very quiet meal, or was there discussion about what was going on? It was a very serious kind of occasion?
segments.answer: Mostly was serious, yes.

segments.question: It was serious. Was there discussion -- once Hitler took power in Germany -
segments.answer: Yi -

segments.question: -- was there discussion around the table about what was going on in Germany?
segments.answer: Ah.

segments.question: Do you remember?
segments.answer: We did discuss it, yes, a little bit.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Not terribly much -

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- but a little bit, yes. I was 14 years old when the war broke out - This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  11

segments.question: Yes, yes -- SO you were -
segments.answer: -- so I was still a young fellow.

segments.question: -- yeah, right. Now you were barmit -- Bar Mitzvahed in -
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: -- 1938, am I correct?
segments.answer: Right, correct.

segments.question: And how long did you study for that?
segments.answer: Oh, I had lessons for a -

segments.question: For the Bar Mitzvah.
segments.answer: For the Bar Mitzvah at home. In school ra -- we had religion as a mandatory subject, and Jewish children would step out and go to a separate classroom -

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: -- where we had a teacher, but we were usually taught Jewish history more than religion.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And -- and at home I was taking preparations for the Bar Mitzvah.

segments.question: And did you like doing that? You didn’t -- is this something you did?
segments.answer: I did it, yes, yeah.

segments.question: And do you remember that day? Do you remember -
segments.answer: Yes, I remember beca -- I -

segments.question: Was there a lot of family there from both sides?
segments.answer: All the family -

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: -- came, and -- and also I gave a little speech. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  12

segments.question: And what did you talk about?
segments.answer: That I don’t know.

segments.question: You don’t remember.
segments.answer: It had to do with a section of the Torah -

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- [had read, yeah, but I don’t remember.

segments.question: You don’t remember. Was there a party afterwards, at the house?
segments.answer: There was a party at our house, yes, a big party, yes.

segments.question: And did you feel proud? Do you remember that -
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: -- as are -- areally important day for you?
segments.answer: It was an important day.

segments.question: And did you feel something changed once -- once you got to be Bar Mitzvahed and they claimed that you were a man now?
segments.answer: Well, I -- yeah, I was also interested because I discovered in the process my father was very proud that his family was Levites, and that is sort of not common, but you know, the three categories, the [indecipherable], the priests, the Levites and [indecipherable] people and I was impressed that I was -

segments.question: A Levi.
segments.answer: -- a Levi.

segments.question: Right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  13
segments.answer: And I must tell you when I was a child, I sometimes had impressions that I will become a prophet. I was very -- I sort of thought always that I was chosen -- a chosen child to do something, so -

segments.question: And was that connected to being a Levi, or did this happen before?
segments.answer: No, this was before.

segments.question: That was before.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: And did you have a particular kind of idea of what you were chosen to do?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: But you felt chosen?
segments.answer: I felt chosen. I felt I was somehow inspired and privileged.

segments.question: Did you ever tell anybody about this when you were a kid?
segments.answer: I told my parents, yes.

segments.question: Yes? And -- and did they respond in a way that was okay?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Did they encourage you?
segments.answer: No, they -

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: -- they were a little surprised.

segments.question: They were surprised. Do you think that -- in 1939 you were 14?
segments.answer: Right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  14

segments.question: Right, when the war comes. Is there any expectation that there’s going to be a war?
segments.answer: Yes, there was expectation -

segments.question: So you expected -
segments.answer: -- there was tension in the air because Germany had post ultimatums demanding that Poland give up the corridor between East Prussia and Germany, and -- and they were threatening, and - and of course, before that was the invasion of Austria by the Germans, so there was a lot of tension. People expected war.

segments.question: And how did that affect you and the household? Was there talk of what you would do if there was a war, or was that not yet -
segments.answer: It was not yet -- there was talk before the war -

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: -- that I might have to go to study at a foreign university because Polish universities were becoming dangerous.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But we had not talked about leaving Poland before the war broke out.

segments.question: And were you -- you may not know what your parents were aware of, but were you in some sense by this time aware of what was going on in Germany’?
segments.answer: Oh, absolutely.

segments.question: And in Austria -
segments.answer: Absolutely.

segments.question: -- with respect to Jews?
segments.answer: Yes, absolutely.

segments.question: You were. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  15
segments.answer: We were -- definitely were, yes.

segments.question: So did this make war that much more frightening to you?
segments.answer: Yes -

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- it definitely made war more frightening.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: We knew Germans had bad intentions towards Jews.

segments.question: Towards Jews.
segments.answer: Yes. And a lot of Germans were -- a lot of Jews were either deported by the Germans into Poland, or were escaping Germany to come to Poland, so that it was common knowledge that things in Germany were just terrible.

segments.question: And were people coming to your house?
segments.answer: Not anybody.

segments.question: Not anybody.
segments.answer: That we knew.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: So, on September first, 1939, when the war broke out and bombs start falling, this must have been, even though you expected it, still a shock because the experience was -
segments.answer: It was still a shock, yes.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: It was just before the school year started and we were still at home expecting to start school, and suddenly the bombs started falling, and -- and there was -- radios were very primitive in This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  16 those days, they had crystal radios and you had to sort of tune them up with whiskers. And we listened. I used to take a radio to -- to bed to listen.

segments.question: And do you remember the first time you heard a bomb?
segments.answer: Sure I do, yes.

segments.question: Can you explain what that was like?
segments.answer: Well, the -- the bombs number -- they -- they explode and they make a lot of noise, and they, you know -

segments.question: Were you sleeping, or was this during the day? Do you re -
segments.answer: Well, we had si -- to -- w-we had blackouts.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: We had to cover the windows, and we taped windows with s-stripes, sort of criss-cross -

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- so that the glass wouldn’t fall and hurt people, so -- and we knew -- it was both at night and in the daytime, yes. And actually, people stood watch in the neighborhood, on the streets, you know, there were sort of like citizen patrols and it was clearly war time.

segments.question: Yeah. And was there an expectation that the Polish army could actually fight well against the Germans, or wasn’t that sure?
segments.answer: Well, at -- at first there was, but it soon became clear that the army was losing ground, and - and my father remembered from the first World War that when a si -- [indecipherable] that sort of advance into central Poland was crossed, that that would mean that the Germans could advance without stopping, and -- and that’s when they started talking about leaving. And first we talked about just my father and I leaving because men were supposed to be in more danger than women, but then they -- my parents conferred and decided that we all should go. And there was This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  17 discussion whether we should go east or south, and my parents weren’t that keen on going towards Russia, so we decided to go south. And we had a car and -- but our car was requisitioned, because the military were requisitioning all the cars. And my uncle had a car, and his car was sort of requisitioned, but he was friendly with the provincial governor in Lwow, and he got the pass to keep the car to take the trip south, but to return it later. So my mother, my aunt conferred and they decided we could go with them. So my aunt and uncle left some suitcases and took us instead.

segments.question: Le-Let me ask you a little bit before. Do you remember the discussions about whether to leave?
segments.answer: Yes, I d -- remember.

segments.question: You do? You were sitting there.
segments.answer: I was sitting there because there was the big question whether we were all going, or whether

segments.question: Or just the two of you?
segments.answer: -- just the two of us.

segments.question: And if it was the two of you, was there talk of your going on a bicycle? Is that right?
segments.answer: That was definitely a talk of going on a bicycle because we didn’t have a car, and my father wasn’t so good on the bicycle and I wasn’t so good either, so -

segments.question: Uh-huh. Now, it seems to me unusual that people would decide so quickly to leave. A lot of people didn’t.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Right? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  18
segments.answer: During first of all the war, my -- independently, my father and my mother’s family went to Vienna to leave the city because it was dangerous to stay in the city, and Vienna was in Austria, so -- so they were used to the notion that -

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: -- if war came, it’s sometimes important to leave [indecipherable]. It was very dramatic to leave, yes.

segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Julian, you -- you ended by saying that it’s very dramatic -- it was a very dramatic time. Would -- could you describe what you -- what happened, and how you packed? If you packed very much, and what you packed?
segments.answer: Well, it was very dramatic thinking about leaving, and we had number of conferences, and we were ask by my aunt and uncle, since there was very little room in the car for -- there were four of us and my aunt and uncle, that’s six people, and we had a driver because neither my father nor my uncle could drive. And so it’s seven people, and so we were asked to take, basically knapsacks, and -- back then, it was, and my mother packed a small suitcase and my father packed a small suitcase. And my sister, very fortunately took pictures, album of pictures, so that was very lucky, and we enjoyed that afterwards. Years later, it was nice to look back and have the photos. But we were -- it wasn’t yet full winter, so 1t was just September, so -

segments.question: Right. It’s very humid, isn’t it?
segments.answer: And -- and -- and the climate -- I mean, it doesn’t get so cold, but it -- but it gets very hot, yeah. And I never really liked the sun so much, so that was one of the problems.

And I became what’s known in Polish as officer cadet, or [speaks Polish] in Polish. segments.question: Mm-hm, right.

segments.question: Uh-huh. I know you were approached by -- with your cousin in the Haganah.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Did anybody for the -- from the Irgun try to enlist you in what they were doing? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  56
segments.answer: No, no.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: And Irgun started quite a bit later. There were rumors that Irgun was being helped with weapons from the Polish army because a lot of the -- a lot of the leaders of Irgun had come with Anders -

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- you know, like Menachem Begin, and -- and there’s actually -- somebody wrote a play called Begin and Anders.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Or Anders and Begin, which -

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- which discusses the relationship. Begin said always that he left on a leave of absence and the Polish army never pursued to get him back, so he w -- as opposed to being a straight deserter, he was actually -- just left on a extended leave of absence.

segments.question: Right. Did you ever meet any of the boys who had left the army? The Jewish boys?
segments.answer: No, no.

segments.question: You never met them?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: So you never got an opportunity to talk to them as to why they made that decision.
segments.answer: No, but I knew some people who made this decision, and it was mostly because they had been through so much turmoil that when they got to Palestine they just thought it was time to end all this wandering around.

segments.question: Right. So let’s go to Italy. You land in Italy. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  57
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: In Taranto, right?
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: In February of 1944, I gather.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Right? And you’re in a light anti-aircraft artillery unit, is that correct?
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: And you’re heading north?
segments.answer: Right. And light anti-aircraft unit, although it was a division -

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- different batteries were assigned to different infantry units, so we were basically in support of infantry.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: W -- we were not like heavy artillery which sits back and shoots, we were -

segments.question: So you’re marching along with infantry?
segments.answer: -- with infantry, right, and each -- each battery sort of separately, so we were seldom together as a whole regiment.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And we -- and the guns were attached to a small truck, and were being pulled by truck, so my next skill was I learned to drive a truck.

segments.question: So you -- so you went from the tank to the truck.
segments.answer: I went from the tank to the truck.

segments.question: And what was the regiment that this unit was from? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  58
segments.answer: This was Fifth Division. Had symbol which was a bison.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And it was called Fifth Krisova divisi -- Krisova meaning the edge of Poland, and it’s the eastern edge of Poland, it’s called Kresse, and the division was in honor of the eastern edge of Poland.

segments.question: So this is part of the second Polish army, the [indecipherable]
segments.answer: Oh, the second Polish division.

segments.question: Division.
segments.answer: Yes. Well, there were actually -- I’m sorry, second Polish army.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Yes. And the second Polish army had the Fifth division and Third division -- Third division and Fifth division. There were not too many divisions.

segments.question: There weren’t?
segments.answer: There were two or three divisions.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And we had British uniforms, but Polish insignia. On our -- our arms here it said Poland.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: And we had a bison for the division and we had a symbol of the British Eighth Army, which happened to be a cross. And -

segments.question: And you wore a beret as well?
segments.answer: And we wore beret, and -- and it was a regular khaki beret, not a black beret like I had in the tanks. And on the beret it was a Polish eagle.

segments.question: With no British sign. Was - This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  59
segments.answer: No, no, no.

segments.question: I see. So you’re traveling north and you’re going to come into one of the biggest battles over there. [indecipherable]
segments.answer: Right, we first fought along the Adriatic on the east coast of Italy.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And then, when we got some way, half way -

segments.question: To Italy.
segments.answer: -- Italy, we were asked to go west and to cross over to the western side. And I think it started somewhere at Forli is the name of the town. And I remember going through a town called Predappio where Mussolini was born and I was very impressed. And actually, before I left Palestine, I went to a lecture once by a former high commissioner of Palestine and he was talking about his military experience in World War I and he was saying one thing he did was because in the army you have a lot of time, he said, I read books, you know, and I was so inspired. He said he picked three most important books and he read them, so I picked the same three books, I think, which was -- one was the Bible, the other one was Macaulay’s “History of England’, and the third one was the history of the Roman empire. And I kept reading them, and also learning Italian as we traveled through Italy. So that then we crossed west, and we went to the area - Montecassino area and mon -

segments.question: Tell me something, y -- y -- go back for a moment. You have a lot of time to read?
segments.answer: Well, in the army you have lot of time, yes.

segments.question: Yeah? Cause you’re waiting a lot?
segments.answer: You’re waiting a lot, yes.

segments.question: Did other boys read as much as you - This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  60
segments.answer: Not as much.

segments.question: -- you were very unusual, yes?
segments.answer: I was maybe more unusual in that respect.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And the other boys learned a little bit of Italian, sort of conver -- conversational Italian.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But I was more really doing systematic self study.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: So then we got to Montecassino, and the situation was that -- and Montecassino is located between Naples and Rome, and this was about the time when the British -- the United States army, U.S. army had landed in Anzio.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And the bri -- American troops were surrounded and stopped there and couldn’t break out. And the critical position was the -- the mountain with the monastery on top, Montecassino mountain. And there were three or four assaults by the British and the French and the Australians and none of them succeeded, and then the Polish troops were called to -- to take their turn at taking the mountain. And our commander, General Anders issued an order of the day in which he said to -- the battle for Montecassino is the battle for freedom of Poland. And Polish soldiers took it to heart and fought very hard, and after a few -- and by the way, at Montecassino, we were -- my unit was made into infantry because the guns couldn’t be pulled up the mountain. And we were all crawling, rock by rock up the mountain and the -- it was -- there was also a lot of bombardment because the British were -- and Americans were dropping bombs on the monastery, which was considered an observation point for German artillery. And the Germans This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  61 were in bunkers all along the mountains, so 1-1t was a very difficult situation. It was in May of44, and then in the end, Polish troops took the monastery at the top of the mountain and mounted the flag, Polish flag and the British flag at the top of the monastery.

segments.question: And -- and what was your -- your role? You were holding what ? What kind of -
segments.answer: I was actually doing some mortar shooting. The mortar we could carry up the mountain, but also with my rifle climbing and making my way up the hill. And -

segments.question: This was not your first battle, or was this a -
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: -- [indecipherable] battle that was this rough for you?
segments.answer: This was the roughest battle, because -- in part because I was not at my gun, but -

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: -- on my own.

segments.question: On your own.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Then who -
segments.answer: And we had to carry the ammunition up the mountain, up the slopes, because cars couldn’t get up there.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: No trucks, no cars.

segments.question: Now I -- as I understand it, there was a first push and it didn’t work, and -- and Anders had to re -- decide what to do now, what sort of a strategy to use to go up the mountain [indecipherable]
segments.answer: Yes, well I was not part of the strategy, but -

segments.question: Right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  62
segments.answer: -- there were several assaults, but -

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- in the end the troops went around, and -

segments.question: Did you get to the top?
segments.answer: I got to the top, yeah.

segments.question: Yes?
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Did many of your buddies get killed, or get hurt in this -
segments.answer: Several of my friends got killed, yes. The casualties were very heavy.

segments.question: Were very high.
segments.answer: And to this date there is a Polish cemetery at the foot of Montecassino that has many graves. And some of them were wounded. I was very lucky to come through.

segments.question: You were -- you weren’t even wounded?
segments.answer: No, I was -

segments.question: That’s very lucky.
segments.answer: -- very lucky, yes.

segments.question: How did it affect you to be in a battle with so many casualties? Was this extremely difficult for you emotionally afterwards?
segments.answer: Well, it was very difficult emotionally while it was going on, but afterwards I felt very lucky to have -- have come through unscathed, yeah.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: And I was very proud also, of having participated in what was a pretty critical battle. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  63

segments.question: Right. And when you think about Anders saying we’re fighting for the freedom of Poland, was that what you were fighting for, or were you fighting for [indecipherable]
segments.answer: Well, I was mostly fighting for the freedom of my relatives and fellow Jews, but -

segments.question: Mm-hm, yes.
segments.answer: -- but they were in Poland, so -

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And at that time we didn’t know yet that eastern Poland had been basically given away by Roosevelt and Churchill to Stalin.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: It was -

segments.question: But by this -- by this time it’s clear to you -
segments.answer: By the -

segments.question: -- that millions of Jews have been killed?
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Right, and -
segments.answer: Right, we -- we knew that already, and -- and I remember at the same time coming across a body of a German and reading a letter he had written to his relatives, or his relatives had written to him, and I could see that they had human problems too, you know, being away from their families, but -- but -- but we knew Jews were being killed in a -

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- brutal way in gas chambers and so on. And we -- when we finished the battle, we were given a break, a little rest.

segments.question: And where did you go? Or did you just stay where you were? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  64
segments.answer: Well, we stayed in the area. I remember once on the mountain, coming across some Moroccan troops which were fren -- part of the French army, and we couldn’t communicate with them too well, so we were just as -- we were scared of them [indecipherable]. The worst thing was walking at night, and you know, in different forests or empty areas and when you stood guard that was pretty difficult situation because sometimes you could be -- Germans could be attacking, you know?

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But that wasn’t at Montecassino, that was elsewhere. We were -- we were also getting leaflets from the Germans. They were dropping leaflets telling us, why are you fighting us, you should - the Russians are killing Poles in -- in Russia. And my friends had all been in Russia, so they all were very aware that the Russians were very bad people. So -- that had -- had them deported, and had them in forced labor, but they wanted to fight the Germans, too.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: I don’t know of anybody who deserted.

segments.question: Uh-huh. So how long was this break after this battle?
segments.answer: It was a short break and we were then sent to the east coast of Italy back again and we fought at -- I fought at -- and the Polish army at Ancona, Bologna, at Loreto, and then at Bologna. And there is a Polish cemetery in Loreto, and there are Jewish graves there, as there are at Montecassino.

segments.question: Who -- who dug graves at Montecassino? Did you boys do it?
segments.answer: I didn’t do it.

segments.question: You didn’t?
segments.answer: No. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  65

segments.question: Did the army do it [indecipherable]
segments.answer: I think the army must have done it, yes. Must have been the army, but they were probably not the front line troops, but the sort of service units.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: Sort of divisional support units.

segments.question: So you’re in a number of other battles along the way?
segments.answer: Right. And -

segments.question: Does it ever -- does it ever get easier before each battle?
segments.answer: No, it wasn’t as difficult as at casino, but it was difficult, for example at one point, we had to retreat and that was very unpleasant. But -- but we -- the British and the Americans were interested in keeping the Italian front active to distract the German troops and extend their supply lines so as to make the landing in France easier, and to make the invasion of France easier. So we weren’t pushed to advance very rapidly, we were going rather slowly.

segments.question: Did you ever come across camps that the Italians had set up, or not?
segments.answer: Not camps -- with Jews? Or camps -

segments.question: Th-They had all sorts of people in the -
segments.answer: Yeah. No, no. We saw some Italians who were si -- fighting on our side. There were some Italians fighting on our side, but I didn't come across Italian camps.

segments.question: And were the Italians that you met happy about your being there?
segments.answer: It was mixed. Most people were afraid of soldiers and soldiers do sometimes take food and wine away from where they -- in the countryside, wherever people tried to -- supplies are difficult during the wars, so sometimes the farmers kept storing things for themselves -

segments.question: Right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  66
segments.answer: -- and sometimes soldiers would take it, and sometimes soldiers would kill chickens.

segments.question: So people were nervous [indecipherable]
segments.answer: So that the Italian -- but the Italians in general were friendly.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: They were not -- there -- there -- it was not hostile territory. And they -- most of them didn’t like the Germans.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Even though some of them were Fascist, you know.

segments.question: But it was a different kind, I guess.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And I remember in Ancona going to the synagogue for high holidays.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: And the army had a rabbi, and occasionally we had services.

segments.question: Hm. Interesting. So in May of 1945, the war is over.
segments.answer: The war was over ra -- around that time. We were approximately at the level Bologna and the war ended and we were very happy. It ended, but there was a question what will become of us, because most of my colleagues like myself were from the eastern part of Poland, which by now we knew was going to become part of Soviet Union. And I -- all the soldiers were given a declaration from England that -- from Britain -- from the British which said that we are encouraged to return to Poland and that they had the commitment that we would be safe when we came back to Poland, or since we had fought on the British side, if we didn’t choose to go back to Poland, we could go to Great Britain. And -- and most of the soldiers went to Great This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  67 Britain, and -- but some who had families returned to Poland. You know, some had left their children and wives at home. And I knew I wasn’t going back to Poland, so -- which was now in Soviet Union, so I had no problem decide -- to become repatriated back to Poland.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: And I was hoping to come to America, and -- but what was very nice is that when the war ended, you know, Anders said, since Poland has lost so many members of its intellectuals, professionals, that he wanted the young military to be educated, and we were offered an opportunity to attend Italian universities. And -- and I opted to go to the Polytechnic in Turin, Italy. A-And some others who want to study medicine went to Bologna, some others went to Rome, some went to Milan. So there were all these Polish young officer cadets, and young officers, who had matriculation and were ready to study and suddenly going to Italian universities and -- and in the -- in Turin there was a sort of dormitory for the Polish soldiers and  who were studying, and I was in that dormitory.

segments.question: And you were still in uniform?
segments.answer: I was in uniform some of the time. I didn’t have so many civilian clothes, but we could be in civilian clothes at that point. And then -

segments.question: Let me -- let me stop you for a moment if I may. When the war is over, are you folks guarding Germans? [indecipherable] prisoners of war?
segments.answer: Oh -- ah -- oh, what happened was, since I knew -- yes, we saw German prisoners of war, and- and si -- w-we were either guarding them or seeing them being guarded by the British. But I am also la -- was assigned to a camp where the British were sorting out people they had liberated. Since I spoke English, I was used as a Polish translator for those who were from Poland. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  68

segments.question: Right. Let’s continue that on the next tape, we’re going to have to stop this tape.
segments.answer: Yeah. End of Tape Four This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  69 Beginning Tape Five

segments.question: Julian, explain what you were doing in this transit camp, for the British.
segments.answer: Yes, I was assigned as an interpreter to a camp where there were a lot of people who had been liberated and were from all different countries. Europe was -- Germans had taken people from different countries for forced labor. From France, from Turkey, from Poland, and from Holland. And when the war ended, somehow we were -- this camp was close to the Austrian border, and a lot of people were brought in, including some who had been in Mauthausen as prisoners of -- as prisoners in the German camp. And some had not been in camps, but had been in forced labor in different factories or doing different jobs. And it was a sea of humanity, and -- and they were out in Open areas, so some of them just warming themselves up by fire. And -- and w -- and some of them were from Russia and from Ukraine. And the British wanted to send all these people home. And there were trains and the job in the camp was sorting people, finding out who they -- where they were from. And some of them didn’t want to go back, in particular the Russians. Some of them were White Russians, who had collaborated with Germans, or who were afraid that they would be accused of having collaborated with German. So it was quite a messy scene and some of them were basically forced onto the trains and -- and also I saw Serbs being take -- Serbs were taken prisoners because they had fought together with the Germans, and they were being shipped back to Serbia. And -- some Serbs, anyway. And -- and -- and there were Polish people, which is why they needed Polish interpreter. And they were trying to figure out who was who and where they should go and where they belonged. And some desperately wanted to go home, and some were afraid to go home. So -

segments.question: And your job was what? To -
segments.answer: To - This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  70

segments.question: -- question them [indecipherable]
segments.answer: -- to question them and get information where they were from, and -- and how they got there. And -

segments.question: What was the -
segments.answer: -- to verify their stories.

segments.question: Right. Were some people more difficult -
segments.answer: It was a British operation.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: I was just assigned as an interpreter.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: It was not a Polish army operation.

segments.question: Now, I -- as I understand it, you met some people who came from Mauthausen, the men.
segments.answer: Right, I met -

segments.question: Was -- that must have been a very difficult story to hear.
segments.answer: It was a very difficult situation to see these people because they were like skeletons and they were basically supporting each other, and barely able to move and walk, and -- and -- and they were still in the striped prisoner gear, yeah.

segments.question: Now is this the first time that you had met -- met anyone, as opposed to just hearing the stories -
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: -- who had been through some of the most difficult -
segments.answer: First time, yes.

segments.question: Uh-huh. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  71
segments.answer: It was the first time.

segments.question: And what did that do to you? Anything?
segments.answer: Well, it moved me very much, and it certainly made me realize what people had been going through during the war.

segments.question: Right. And were you in favor of what the British were trying to do, or did you think this was wrong?
segments.answer: Well, I was in favor of people being sent home, but I think there could have been a little more humanity to it.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And they didn’t have the amenities. Some of them -- some of them were -- they were being packed -- sometimes when I see the movie like “Shoah”, and I see how the Germans packed people, it wasn’t that bad, but it was -- some of 1t was forced packing of people onto trains.

segments.question: Uh-huh. And how long were you doing this? A month, two months?
segments.answer: Probably like a couple of months, yeah.

segments.question: Uh-huh. And was it after that that you were given the opportunity to go to Turin and go to the university?
segments.answer: Yes, it was after that, yes.

segments.question: Did you happen to know that Primo Levi, was he anybody that was known, wh-who came back to Turin, who lived there for the rest of his life?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: No, I didn’t.

segments.question: Not at the time. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  72
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Did you like going to the university there?
segments.answer: Well, I liked very much, yes.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: It was a relief and a reprieve after service in the military and then we again all got along very well, and -- and we were like a close group together.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Eventually I moved out of the dormitory to a private apartment with another Polish colleague.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: With whom I’m still in touch, you know, lives in Florida, he’s a Catholic, but he calls me up very often.

segments.question: Now tell me something, because people may not know, was there a lot of destruction in Italy, because it seems -- 1t could seem surprising that a university would be open -
segments.answer: Well, in Turin there was very little destruction.

segments.question: Very little.
segments.answer: Almost no destruction.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Turin, Genoa, Milan, were not really destructed too much.

segments.question: Yeah. And your Italian was good enough to go to the university?
segments.answer: Yes, my Italian -

segments.question: By then, yes?
segments.answer: -- was quite good, yes. And I took a sort of engineering course, yeah. First year of engineering it was called. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  73

segments.question: So, are you, throughout this period, are you able in some way to communicate with your parents? Are you a -
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: -- and your sister, you’re able to write?
segments.answer: I was able to write and send letters, and once I was even given a leave of absence during the war to go back to Palestine and visit my parents.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: By boat, of course.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Yeah. And with a few other Polish friends -

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- who had relatives in Tel Aviv, or some -

segments.question: So that must have been a very nice thing for you to [indecipherable] to do.
segments.answer: It was a nice interlude, yeah.

segments.question: And did you then, when you met your parents and your sister, discuss what you would do? Cause it was clear that the allies were going to win by this time.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: I mean, it probably was clear even before.
segments.answer: Right. And we at that time started corresponding with my aunt who was then in New York, and -

segments.question: Now this is the same aunt, this is the sister -
segments.answer: The same aunt, yes.

segments.question: The [indecipherable] right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  74
segments.answer: Yes. And we were trying to get a visa to come to the United States, and -- and actually, at one point I -- my aunt [indecipherable] was in her second marriage. In her first marriage, her married name was Ulam, and her nephew, son of her husband’s dead -- the husband died, she was a widow before she remarried. And he was in the United States, his name was Stan Ulam. He was- later became known for inventing the hydrogen bomb. But he was at University Southern California and he was a mathematician, an outstanding, world famous mathematician. And he also then went to New Mexico, or to -- to Los Alamos to participate in the development of the bomb. And he was well connected, and he got me an admission to the University of Southern California. So I went to the consulate 1n Genoa to see the American consul to pick up the visa, and the consul asked me, do you want to stay in the United States? And I said, of course. And it was absolutely the wrong answer, because the moment I said that, I couldn’t get the student visa, because student visa is only for temporary stay as a student.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: So the consul said, you have to apply for regular immigration visa. And Polish quota was very tight because at those ti -- in those days, each country had a quota, and since a lot of people from Poland were displaced, the Polish quota was very difficult to -- to get the immigration visa, and it was like a three year wait. So I didn’t get the immigration visa til after I got to London. So my trip to Genoa was wasted, but my aunt finally send me the -- the papers to -- affidavit to -- to apply for the visa.

segments.question: Now, are your -- your parents and sister trying to get to the United States at the same time?
segments.answer: My parents and sister -- well, my sister went to study in Beirut, Lebanon, because she didn’t want to study in English or in Hebrew. S -- and she was interested in French, and in Beirut she first went to the English university, but transferred then to the French university, she studied This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  75 medicine. And so my sister was already in Beirut, not with my parents, and I was in the army. And the British then offered to evacuate Poles from Palestine. Just before they were going to leave Palestine, they evacuated Poles who wanted to leave, to Great Britain. And my parents communicate with my sister and she came and together they left from Palestine to -- to go to England, yeah. And I was already in England at that time.

segments.question: Oh, so you got there before.
segments.answer: I got there before.

segments.question: And so you were -
segments.answer: The British didn’t want to keep Polish soldiers in Italy too long.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And actually, the better student you were, the longer you could stay. So I stayed quite long in Italy to complete my first year of engineering, and then I had to leave.

segments.question: Right. Now, was there any thought on your parent’s part to stay in Palestine?
segments.answer: Not really, no.

segments.question: No, uh-huh. And you had no interest to go -
segments.answer: To return back, no. I was interest to start a new life.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And when I got to England, the British wanted to have better control over Polish soldiers in England so they put -- so they incorporated us into something called Polish resettlement corps.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Polish resettlement corps was a British unit for Polish soldiers. It was not to fight, it was just to control them. And then, people who were in Polish resettlement corps could either get leave of absence to go to study, or they had to go to work. In Britain at that time there was compulsory This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  76 labor actually, yo-you had to work, so you had to report to the employment office, and they would assign you a job if you couldn’t find one.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And a lot of Poles ended up in coal mines, and -- because [indecipherable] Britain, so -- but I was one of those lucky ones who were given a -- an -- an -- an opportunity to go to London and study, and I started in something called Polish University College, which doesn’t exist any more, but was preparing Polish former soldiers to take degr -- amer -- British degrees. And at that time University of London had a program which was called external program, so that you didn’t have to attend the university, you could just take exams as an external student. And I couldn’t get into any British university, they were all fully booked, so I went to this Polish University College, and I start preparing for what’s called part one of the Bachelor’s degree for the University of London external examination. And then -- and I took that examination and when I passed I transferred to Worcester Polytechnic, which was sort of a college, but again the exams were external University of London exams, and I was preparing for part two, and I was going through it pretty quickly so that by 1949, when I was 24, I was ready to take the Bachelor’s degree exam, but then my visa arrived from the United States, and the American consul would not renew it. I wanted to wait til June, it was March, and he said he couldn’t renew the visa, I would have to go to back of the line. So I went to the university office, and I asked them whether I could go and take the external examination in Canada, which was at that time a British -- part of British empire. And the -- well, I said even maybe should come back to London because be it’d be cheaper than taking a whole year of study.

segments.question: Right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  77
segments.answer: And they said, well what we will do, we will send you the examination papers to New York. So I did my Bachelor’s degree -

segments.question: In New York?
segments.answer: -- in New York. I was at Columbia University under the supervision of somebody the British designated to supervise I was not cheating.

segments.question: Did your parent and sister go before you?
segments.answer: My parents, sister left for United States before me, yes.

segments.question: And they -- and -
segments.answer: Because they had no reason to stay -

segments.question: To stay.
segments.answer: -- behind, yeah.

segments.question: But when your parents were in [indecipherable]
segments.answer: Actually my sister went from England back to Beirut to pass her final examination to become a physician, and then she came back.

segments.question: And then she came to the United States. The period of time that your parents were in England, were you living together?
segments.answer: When we were living in England we were not living together, no. I lived in Kent, near Worcester Polytechnic.

segments.question: I see. And was your father working [indecipherable] and your mother? What was going on?
segments.answer: My father was doing some kind of menial work and my mother was sewing and earning money by sewing, yes.

segments.question: Uh-huh. So the period of time when you were in Palestine, while you were in the army, fighting, was she mainly supporting the family by her sewing? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  78
segments.answer: She was supporting and I think they were getting a stipend from the Polish government.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Like all the refugees.

segments.question: Right. So -
segments.answer: That’s most likely.

segments.question: Uh-huh. So did everybody land in New York? Is that where you [indecipherable |
segments.answer: Well, my parents landed in New York and my sister, and they moved into an apartment and my father got different jobs selling newspapers in a kiosk and making deliveries and my mother kept sewing.

segments.question: Sewing.
segments.answer: She ended up becoming an expert at sewing ties and it was piecework, so she worked very hard. And I arrived in New York, and the first few months I prepared for my final exam.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: And then I looked for a job and I couldn’t find any because when -- for good -- there was a shortage of good jobs. I didn’t know whether I had yet received my Bachelor’s degree, because the papers went through Britain by boat and the results were not in. And -- and my sister worked as an intern in a hospital, but she wasn’t making much money either, and -- and when I -- it was a menial job they thought I was too well educated, they didn't want to give me a menial job. So in the meanwhile, when I was in London I had applied for college in America, not knowing I was going to get the degree from London, and a fre -- friend suggested that I apply to MIT and I got admitted, but I didn’t have money to go and some kind person in New York -- the Jewish family service send me to somebody and he lend me some money and I went then to MIT. And when I arrived at MIT, I was told that since I didn’t have yet my Bachelor’s degree, because in This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  79 September it wasn’t yet known whether I had passed in June or not, believe it or not and they said it depended how well I passed before they could admit me to graduate school. A -- th -- and I didn’t want to become an undergraduate because I thought I’d passed, so they made me a special student. And there was a bit of a disaster because special student can’t get the scholarship.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: So -- and there 1s an organization in Boston called -- at that time there was an organization in Boston on Mount Auburn Street where they were helping Jewish immigrants and they gave me a loan and I also got a job at -- part-time job at MIT, so I finished for a few months as special student, then my matriculation results -- my Bachelor’s degree results arrived and they admitted me to graduate school, so -

segments.question: Uh-huh. And then you got your -
segments.answer: And then I became an assistant [indecipherable] the scholarship, yeah.

segments.question: And what degree did you get from MIT?
segments.answer: I got a Master’s degree in electrical engineering, yeah.

segments.question: [indecipherable]. And then you went to Harvard for Ph.D.?
segments.answer: Then I went to work for Lincoln Laboratory, which was located in those days at MIT. And I got admitted at Harvard for a Ph.D., and I was commuting -- working -- I was both working at Lincoln Laboratory, going to Harvard, it was slightly illegal because you’re not supposed to be a full-time employee when you are -

segments.question: A student.
segments.answer: -- when you’re a full-time student.

segments.question: Right. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  80
segments.answer: So [used to pick my classes early in the morning or on Saturdays, or -- or at lunch hour.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: But -- and then I got the scholarship from Harvard, and I transferred there -- went full-time.

segments.question: And what happened to your sister? She got a degree in medicine, but certainly she couldn’t just use it in the United States, she would have to take another exam, yes?
segments.answer: Ah, right, she, I believe, did take another exam. But my sister then -- my sister had been in love with somebody in Beirut who was her instructor, actually, he was professor of medicine and he came to New York, and they got married, and she went back to Beirut.

segments.question: She went back to Beirut?
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Oh my. And she remained there?
segments.answer: And she remained there, and was -- I -- when we got married we went to visit her and then when the fighting broke out in Lebanon she came for a short time to New York and then she went back, yeah.

segments.question: Yeah. Is she still alive?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: No.

segments.answer: Exactly.
