segments.question: Julian, tell -- tell me a little bit about what you did once you got your degrees from Harvard and MIT. What work did you do all these years?
segments.answer: I was mostly in -- I became a specialist 1n communication theory and signal processing and I first worked on development of radar and then on development of visual communications or radio communications in particular. And I first worked at Lincoln Laboratory, and then I worked at RCA and then I started my own company.

segments.question: How -- how did you happen to narrow the field? I -- I’m assuming this is -- is part of the field of electrical engineering, am I right?
segments.answer: Correct, yes.

segments.question: And if that’s the case, how do you -- how did you narrow it down to these particular aspects?
segments.answer: I looked for the most mathematical part of electrical engineering.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: And that turned out to be signal processing and what’s called statistical communication theory.

segments.question: Uh-huh. But this led you also to work a great deal with the military, I gather?
segments.answer: Right, I worked quite a bit military research and development and with NASA. And very proud I contributed to the first landing on the moon because I assisted in the selection of radars for them, and testing them for -- for the landing on the moon.

segments.question: Really? So were -- were you there when -- when the lift-off happened?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No?
segments.answer: No, I was not there, I watched it on televisions. This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  84

segments.question: On television like the rest of us.
segments.answer: And I was very excited.

segments.question: I bet you were. And you worked for how long? When did you retire? Just -
segments.answer: I retired formerly in 1987.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: But I continue still consulting.

segments.question: You do?
segments.answer: Yes. And I occasionally write something and I just recently wrote a chapter for encyclopedial telecommunications.

segments.question: I see. When -- when you look back on your life, do you see that your experiences had an important influence on how you lived your life after the war?
segments.answer: Definitely, yes.

segments.question: An-And how would you characterize that?
segments.answer: Well, first of all, having served in the military and having had ups and downs in my own life, I learned that money is very valuable, but that you really -- well, it’s more important that you feel good and do the right thing. And -- and I learned to respect people in every walk of life. And - and sometimes I found different people helped me in different situations and some of them were not my buddies, and -- and also I learned to not give up easily and to have faith that I can get out of a situation, and if it was difficult for example, in business, I learned to persist and -- and try to find a way to solve problems. And I kind of got -- I get very challenged to -- when I’m in adversity, to deal with it. And I think I’ve taught my children that.

segments.question: And how do you relate that to the -- do you think -- well, I don’t know how -- whether you can even answer this question. Had you not escaped, had your not -- not -- your parents shown This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  85 you that there are other ways to handle things, it might have been easier to become depressed, or- or not have such a hopeful outlook.
segments.answer: Well, I actually am determined not to become depressed.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And my mother at one point became depressed and I felt s-so miserable about it, and saw her so miserable that I decided -

segments.question: That you wouldn’t. [indecipherable |
segments.answer: I will not let myself become depressed, under any circumstances. And I -- I -- I kind of sometimes welcomed the challenge. I -- I don’t regard it as adversity, I regard it as something to overcome, when there is a problem.

segments.question: And I understand that you are very involved in Polish Jewish relations and involved with those Poles with -- who were not Jewish necessarily, who went though similar experiences to you. [indecipherable]
segments.answer: That’s right. I -- I -- I feel that the people who went through it, we really had all very good relations. Now, this was not true of survivors, some of whom are very bitter that some their friends denounced them. And on the other hand there are people who survived who were saved by Poles. It was almost impossible to survive without some assistance from somebody. But I’m interested in seeing Polish Jewish relations become normal, and -- and this is impossible unless you participate and try to do it, y-you can’t just say I won’t have anything to do with these people and hope that relations can become normalized. And I believe it’s important that people get along no matter what nationality they are, and what ethnic group they are and what religion they are.

segments.question: And do you see improvements in the relationship of Polish Jews and Polish Gentiles? This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  86
segments.answer: I see improvements particularly among educated people and we are amazed when we sometimes go to Poland, in recent years we have gone to Poland almost every year, that there are some people who become very interested in -- in Jewish history and contribution of Jews. Jews who are 10 percent of Poland. And I think some of it has been the German propaganda that sort of separated Jews into umensch, which means, not a man, inhumans basically.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And -- and also Soviet propaganda which was against Palestine, and against Zionism, and - and some of this is the Soviet and German inf -- a-and, you know, the Germans have become democratic country now, and -- and Communism is dead and some of it is disappearing in Poland, but there is still, particularly among people who are deprived, who look to be either better than somebody, or to be mean to somebody and compensate for their depravation, no matter whether the person is guilty of their depravation or not. And some of these people are still sort of anti-Semitic -

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- but the more intelligent people are not, I don’t think. And so I am active in -- in -- both in trying to document Polish Jewish history and in Polish Jewish relations.

segments.question: Relations. And tell me when you met your wife.
segments.answer: I met my wife around -- I’m not very good at dates, but I think it was around 1958.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: And -- and I was already working and my wife was still a student and she -- and I met her at a party, and at first she wasn’t interested in me, but then one day I arranged to meet her finally, and she asked me some questions about my past and she became interested and -- and then our romance was partly my telling her the story of my life and then it turn out her father had been This is a verbatim transcript of spoken word. It is not the primary source, and it has not been checked for spelling or accuracy. http://collections.ushmm.org Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about this collection  87 from Poland himself, and he came here just before the World War I, and she was listening to what I had to say and gradually our friendship grew.

segments.answer: We got married in 1960.

segments.question: Oh good, you remembered that.
segments.answer: It’s a -- that’s one easy -- because it ends in zero, that’s an -

segments.question: That’s an -- it’s an easy date [indecipherable]
segments.answer: -- easy date, yes. And it was really, I think a very fortunate experience for me, and -

segments.question: And you have three children?
segments.answer: We had three children, two girls and one son and our daughters are 38 and 35 now and our son is 33. And we have done a lot of family traveling, yeah. We went to Poland and actually to Ukraine with the children, so -- in 1989, when the Iron Curtain dropped. I had been afraid to go to Poland before I retired because I was working in defense industry, but then after I retired and Gorbachev came to power or something, we decided to go and visit Lwow.

segments.answer: And we went as a family to show them. Actually, my -- I didn’t want to go at first, but my wife insisted, so we -

segments.question: Right. And you have eight grandchildren?
segments.answer: We have eight gran-grandchildren, yes.
